Homemade Mac and Cheese with Gruyere and Parmesan

Jump to Recipe

Welcome to your new favorite comfort food recipe: Homemade Mac and Cheese with Gruyere and Parmesan! This creamy, cheesy delight is a classic dish that can warm hearts and fill bellies, making it the perfect addition to any family gathering or cozy night in. With the rich flavors of Gruyere and the sharpness of Parmesan, this mac and cheese takes a traditional recipe and elevates it to gourmet status without sacrificing the simplicity that makes it a beloved staple. In this article, we will guide you through each step of creating this mouthwatering dish, ensuring that your homemade mac and cheese is both delicious and satisfying. Whether you're an experienced chef or a novice in the kitchen, our easy-to-follow instructions and tips will help you whip up a batch that will have everyone asking for seconds!

Ingredients

macaroni pasta

For a healthier option, consider using whole wheat macaroni or gluten-free pasta. Ensure you cook it al dente, as it will continue to cook when baked.

butter

You can substitute with olive oil or vegan butter for a healthier or dairy-free alternative. For added flavor, try browning the butter before adding it to the roux.

all-purpose flour

For a gluten-free version, use a gluten-free all-purpose flour blend or cornstarch. If you want a nutty flavor, try using almond flour, but adjust the quantity as it may thicken differently.

milk

You can substitute with any non-dairy milk such as almond, soy, or oat milk. For a richer flavor, use half-and-half or cream instead of milk.

gruyere cheese, shredded

If Gruyere is unavailable, Emmental or a sharp cheddar can work as substitutes. Mixing in some smoked cheese can also enhance the flavor.

parmesan cheese, grated

For a more intense flavor, try using Pecorino Romano instead of Parmesan. Nutritional yeast can be used for a dairy-free cheesy flavor.

salt

Adjust the amount based on the saltiness of your cheese. If using unsalted butter, consider increasing the salt slightly.

black pepper

Freshly ground black pepper will provide a stronger flavor. For a kick, consider adding a pinch of cayenne or paprika.

breadcrumbs (optional)

For added crunch and flavor, try using panko breadcrumbs or mixing in some grated cheese with the breadcrumbs before sprinkling on top.

Cooking Steps

  • Step 1: Cook the Macaroni Pasta

    Bring a large pot of salted water to a boil. Add 8 ounces of macaroni pasta and cook according to package instructions until al dente, usually about 7-8 minutes. Drain the pasta and set it aside. Note: Adding salt to the water enhances the flavor of the pasta.

  • Step 2: Make the Roux

    In a large saucepan, melt 2 tablespoons of butter over medium heat. Once melted, add 2 tablespoons of all-purpose flour. Stir continuously for about 1 minute to cook the flour slightly, creating a roux. Tip: Ensure you don’t let the roux brown; it should remain a light golden color.

  • Step 3: Add the Milk

    Gradually whisk in 2 cups of milk to the roux, ensuring there are no lumps. Continue stirring constantly until the mixture thickens, which should take about 3-5 minutes. Expert Tip: Use whole milk for a creamier texture, or you can substitute half-and-half for extra richness.

  • Step 4: Incorporate the Cheeses

    Remove the saucepan from heat and stir in 1 cup of shredded Gruyere cheese and 1/2 cup of grated Parmesan cheese until fully melted and smooth. Season the cheese sauce with 1/2 teaspoon of salt and 1/4 teaspoon of black pepper. Note: Gruyere cheese gives a nutty flavor, while Parmesan adds a sharpness.

  • Step 5: Combine Macaroni and Cheese Sauce

    Add the drained macaroni to the cheese sauce, stirring well until all the pasta is coated. If you prefer a baked version, transfer the mixture to a greased baking dish. Optional: Sprinkle 1/4 cup of breadcrumbs on top for added crunch. Expert Tip: You can mix in cooked bacon or vegetables for extra flavor.

  • Step 6: Bake the Mac and Cheese

    Preheat your oven to 350°F (175°C). Place the baking dish in the oven and bake for about 10 minutes, or until the top is golden and bubbly. Tip: For an extra crispy top, switch to broil for the last 2 minutes, but watch closely to avoid burning.

Frequently Asked Questions

How do I know when pasta is cooked 'al dente'?

Al dente means 'to the tooth' in Italian. Pasta cooked al dente should be firm to the bite but not hard. Start checking the pasta a minute or two before the package instructions say it's done. It should be slightly undercooked since it will continue to cook in the cheese sauce.

What is a roux and how do I make one?

A roux is a mixture of fat (in this case, butter) and flour used to thicken sauces. To make a roux, melt the butter in a saucepan over medium heat, then whisk in the flour until smooth. Cook for about a minute to get rid of the raw flour taste, stirring constantly.

How can I ensure my cheese sauce is smooth and creamy?

Make sure to gradually whisk in the milk after the roux has cooked. Adding it slowly helps prevent lumps. Stir constantly and cook until the sauce thickens before adding the shredded cheese.

Can I substitute different types of cheese?

Yes, you can use other cheeses like cheddar, mozzarella, or a mix of your favorites. Just keep in mind that the flavor and texture might change. Gruyere adds a nice nutty flavor, while Parmesan offers sharpness.

What can I do if my cheese sauce is too thick?

If your cheese sauce is too thick, simply add a little more milk, a tablespoon at a time, while stirring until you reach your desired consistency.

What's the purpose of breadcrumbs on top?

Breadcrumbs add a crunchy texture to the top of the mac and cheese after baking, offering a nice contrast to the creamy sauce. You can mix them with a bit of melted butter for extra flavor.

How do I safely handle hot pots and pans?

Always use oven mitts or pot holders to handle hot cookware. Ensure your work area is clear and dry to prevent slipping, and be cautious of steam when removing lids.

How do I clean up after cooking?

Start by clearing away any food scraps, then wash your pots and pans while they are still warm to make cleaning easier. Wipe down surfaces with a damp cloth and keep your workspace organized for a smoother cooking experience next time.

What if I don't have a baking dish?

If you don't have a baking dish, you can use any oven-safe dish, such as a cast-iron skillet or a casserole dish. Just make sure it’s suitable for the oven.

How long can I store leftovers and how should I do it?

Leftover mac and cheese can be stored in an airtight container in the refrigerator for 3-5 days. To reheat, add a splash of milk before warming it in the microwave or on the stovetop to keep it creamy.

Additional Information

Dietary Considerations

To make the mac and cheese gluten-free, substitute the macaroni with gluten-free pasta and use a gluten-free all-purpose flour for the roux. For a dairy-free version, use a plant-based butter, non-dairy milk (like almond or oat milk), and substitute the cheeses with vegan cheese alternatives that melt well. Those who are lactose-intolerant can also opt for lactose-free dairy products. Additionally, consider adding cooked vegetables like spinach or roasted red peppers for added nutrition and flavor.

Pairings

For a delightful meal, serve the mac and cheese with a side of roasted Brussels sprouts drizzled with balsamic reduction to complement the richness of the dish. A crisp green salad with a light vinaigrette can also balance the creaminess. As for beverages, pair it with a chilled Chardonnay or a light-bodied lager, which will cut through the richness of the cheese. For a non-alcoholic option, consider a sparkling apple cider for a refreshing contrast.

Serving Suggestions

Serve the mac and cheese hot, ideally in individual ramekins for a gourmet touch. Garnish each serving with a sprinkle of freshly chopped parsley or chives to add color and freshness. You can also offer a variety of hot sauces on the side for guests who enjoy a bit of heat. For a cozy presentation, serve in a cast-iron skillet, which retains heat well and adds a rustic flair to the meal.

Homemade Mac and Cheese with Gruyere and Parmesan

30 min
$6
450 kcal
Difficulty: 20%
Servings: 4

Allergens:

DairyGluten

Dietary Tags:

Course:

Tags:

Comfort FoodQuickEasy

Description

Creamy, cheesy, and incredibly comforting, this mac and cheese is elevated with the nutty flavors of Gruyere and the sharpness of Parmesan.

Ingredients

  • macaroni pasta: 8 ounces
  • butter: 2 tablespoons
  • all-purpose flour: 2 tablespoons
  • milk: 2 cups
  • gruyere cheese, shredded: 1 cup
  • parmesan cheese, grated: 1/2 cup
  • salt: 1/2 teaspoon
  • black pepper: 1/4 teaspoon
  • breadcrumbs (optional): 1/4 cup
